sen.j: 湯起請（ゆきしょう）とは、主に裁判の際に、二人の内どちらの主張が正しいかを審理する方法。
sen.e: Yugisho is a judgment method that was mainly used in trials to determine which of the two person's claim was right.
sen.cmt: ウェブの用語には「主張=insistence」と登録されていますが、裁判の主張の場合には"claim"を使うと思いますので"claim"としました。
sen.e: Yugisho is a method that was mainly used in trials to judge which of the two claimants involved had a just claim.
Yugisho is a method that was mainly used in trials to judge which of the two claimants involved had a just claim.

sen.j: 湯立（ゆだて）とも呼ばれている。
sen.e: It is also called yudate.
It is also known as yudate.
It is also known as yudate.

sen.j: 湯起請の方法は、まずあらかじめ審理を受ける者二人が、それぞれ自分の主張が事実であると、当事者の前で誓う（起請文を作成する場合もある）。
sen.e: In yugisho method, first of all, each of the two persons to be tried have to swear that their claim is a fact in front of the parties concerned (in some cases they create kishomon (sworn oath)).
In the yugisho method, each of the two claimants to be tried first swore that their claim was the truth in front of the parties concerned (in some cases, they would write a kishomon (sworn oath)).
In the yugisho method, each of the two claimants to be tried first swore that their claim was the truth in front of the parties concerned (in some cases, they would write a kishomon [sworn oath]).
sen.cmt: 指示書に従い、二重括弧を[]としました。

sen.j: その上で、神に審議を問うという形で、二人が同時に熱湯の中に入った石を取り出して神棚に安置する。
sen.e: After that, the two persons simultaneously put their hands in boiling water, take out a stone, and then enshrine it on the Shinto altar in order to ask the god for consideration.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After that, they would both simultaneously put their hands in boiling water, take out a stone, and then place it on the Shinto altar in order to ask the shrine's gods for consideration.
After that, they would both simultaneously put their hands in boiling water, take out a stone, and then place it on the Shinto altar in order to ask the shrine's gods for consideration.

sen.j: その後当日もしくは数日後に、焼けただれ（これを「失」と称する）の少ない者の主張が正しいと判断する方法である。
sen.e: Later on the same day or a few days later, if one of the persons suffers less scald (it is referred to "shitsu" (fault)) his claim is judged as right.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Then, on the same day or a few days later, the claimant who suffered a less severe scald (it was referred to as "shitsu" [fault]) would be judged to be right.
sen.cmt: 読みやすいよう表現を少し変えました。
sen.e: Then, on the same day or a few days later, the claimant who suffered a less severe scald (it was referred to as "shitsu" [fault]) would be judged to be right.

sen.j: ただし、当日の他行・不参、石の取り出し及び棚への安置の失敗による取り落としなどがあれば、直ちに「失あり」とされて敗訴となった。
sen.e: However, if a person went out somewhere else or did not attend on the trial day, or failed to take out a stone or dropped the stone when enshrining it on the altar, the person was considered as "at fault" and he would lose the suit.

However, if on the day of the trial, the claimant went out somewhere else, did not attend the trial, failed to take out the stone, or place it on the altar by dropping it, he would be considered to be "at fault" and lose the suit immediately.
sen.cmt: 読みやすいよう表現を少し変えました。
sen.e: However, if on the day of the trial, the claimant went out somewhere else, did not attend the trial, failed to take out the stone, or place it on the altar by dropping it, he would be considered to be "at fault" and lose the suit immediately.

sen.j: なお、両方とも火傷の程度が同じである場合には、双方折半の神意の表れと解された。
sen.e: If both persons suffer the similar degree of scalds, it was regarded as a providence that shows they were fifty-fifty.
If the both claimants suffered the similar degree of scalds, it would be regarded as a providence that shows they were even.
If the both claimants suffered a similar degree of scalding, it would be regarded as a sign from providence showing that their claims were even.
sen.cmt: 自然な英語に直しました。

sen.j: 主に境相論などの民事的な訴訟で行われたが、各種犯罪の嫌疑者個人に対して行われた例も存在する。
sen.e: Although yugisho was mainly used for civil suits such as disputes over the boundaries of territories, some examples show that it was used for individual suspects of various crimes.
Although yugisho was mainly applied to civil suits such as disputes over the boundary between territories, in some cases it was used on a suspect of various crimes.
sen.cmt: 分かりやすいよう、後半部の表現を少し変えました。
sen.e: Although yugisho was mainly applied to civil suits such as disputes over the boundary between territories, in some cases it was used on a suspect of various crimes.

sen.j: 古代の盟神探湯を継承したと考えられているが、律令法時代にはこうした手法は存在しない。
sen.e: It is considered that yugisho inherited kugatachi (a way of decision putting one's hand in hot water) from ancient times, however, no such technique existed in Ritsuryo law period.

Yugisho is considered to be an inheritance of kukatachi (an ancient way of making a judgment by putting one's hands in hot water) from ancient times, but no such technique existed in the period of the Ritsuryo legal codes.
sen.cmt: 文法ミスがあるため、修正しました。百科事典マイペディアより、「kukatachi」を採用します。
sen.e: Yugisho is considered to be an inheritance of kukatachi (an ancient way of making a judgment by putting one's hands in hot water) from ancient times, but no such technique existed in the period of the Ritsuryo legal codes.

sen.j: 盟神探湯の復活と言う形で室町時代前期頃から行われたとみられているが詳細は不明であるが、当初は民間で行われていたと考えられている。
sen.e: Although the details are unknown, it is said that yugisho was brought back as kugatachi and started being used around the early Muromachi period, and it is considered that it was used for ordinary citizens at first.
Although the details are unknown, it is said that yugisho started being used around the early Muromachi period as a revival of the ancient kukatachi and was used among private citizens at first.
sen.cmt: 文法ミスと分かりづらい表現があるため、修正しました。
sen.e: Although the details are unknown, it is said that yugisho started being used around the early Muromachi period as a revival of the ancient kukatachi and was used among private citizens at first.

sen.j: 強制的な拘束や拷問などを行わずに「神の意思」の名のもとで当事者の合意を得られる方法として広く行われたが、あくまでも双方の証人・証文などの証拠類を揃えて吟味した結果でも事実の成否が確定できない場合などに限定されていた。
sen.e: It was widely used as a method to obtain agreement from the parties concerned without detentions or tortures under the name of "the will of the god", however, its use was limited only to the cases where it could not be determined whether the fact was true or false even after thorough investigation of evidences (such as witnesses/deeds) of the both parties.

It was widely used as a method which enabled people to obtain agreements from both claimants without the exercise of detentions or tortures at "the will of the gods," but its use was limited only to the cases in which the truth could not be ascertained even after the thorough investigation of evidence such as witnesses or documents collected from the both parties.
sen.cmt: 文法ミスと分かりづらい表現があるため、修正しました。
sen.e: It was widely used as a method which enabled people to obtain agreements from both claimants without the exercise of detentions or tortures at "the will of the gods," but its use was limited only to the cases in which the truth could not be ascertained even after the thorough investigation of evidence such as witnesses or documents collected from the both parties.

sen.j: また、実際に湯起請を行うことを決めるだけで訴訟当事者に心理的圧迫を与えられ、証拠があやふやな当事者の訴訟取下などの早期解決に至らせる間接的な効力も有した。
sen.e: In fact, since the decision to conduct yugisho could put psychological pressure on the litigant parties, it was indirectly effective to make the litigants with vague evidence drop the suit and achieve an early solution.

Also, since the decision to conduct yugisho could put psychological pressure on the litigants, indirectly it helped to achieve an early solution to a problem by having litigants with weak evidence drop the suit voluntarily.
sen.cmt: 若干読みやすくするため表現を変えました。
sen.e: Also, since the decision to conduct yugisho could put psychological pressure on the litigants, indirectly it helped to achieve an early solution to a problem by having litigants with weak evidence drop the suit voluntarily.

sen.j: 応永32年（1425年）に朝廷の内侍所で湯起請が行われたことが『薩戒記』に記載され、『看聞御記』にも永享3年（1431年）に湯起請が行われたことが記されている。
sen.e: According to "Sakkai-ki Diary", yugisho was conducted at Naishidokoro (place where sacred mirror is enshrined) of the Imperial Court in 1425, and also in 1431 according to "Kanmongyoki".

"Sakkai-ki Diary" mentions that yugisho was conducted at Naishidokoro (the place where the sacred mirror is enshrined) of the Imperial Court in 1425, and also "Kanmongyoki" that it was conducted in 1431.
sen.cmt: I don't know if this sentence makes sense.
sen.e: In "Sakkai-ki Diary," it is stated that yugisho was conducted at Naishidokoro (the place where the sacred mirror is enshrined) of the Imperial Court in 1425, and also in "Kanmongyoki," it is described that it was conducted in 1431.
sen.cmt: it is stated that~it is described that~としました。

sen.j: また、永享11年の室町幕府の意見書でも「湯起請の失の深浅は、牓示姧曲の多少による」とされ、不当な主張をすれば湯起請の結果に反映されるとして、境相論の解決法として有効とみなしていた。
sen.e: A written opinion of Muromachi bakufu from 1439 describes that "the degree of shitsu depends on how maliciously Boji (signs placed at the borders of territories) was distorted", and thus unreasonable claims were considered to be reflected to the result of yugisho, therefore, it was recognized as an effective solution for disputes over the boundaries of territories.
sen.cmt: 「牓示姧曲」の意味がよくわかりません。姧曲=奸曲とも書き、「心に悪だくみのある・こと（さま）」という意味のようです。文脈から、「牓示をどの程度歪曲して主張しているか」というような意味に解釈しました。
sen.e: A written opinion issued by the Muromachi bakufu in 1439 described that "the degree of shitsu shows how maliciously Boji (signs placed at the border between territories) was distorted" and regarded it as an effective solution to disputes over the boundary between territories since an unreasonable claim would be reflected in the the result of yugisho.
sen.cmt: 文法ミスがあるため修正しました。
sen.e: A written opinion issued by the Muromachi bakufu in 1439 described that "the degree of shitsu shows how maliciously Boji (signs placed at the border between territories) was distorted" and regarded it as an effective solution to disputes over the boundary between territories since an unreasonable claim would be reflected in the the result of yugisho.

sen.j: なお、室町幕府においても湯起請には作法があった。
sen.e: The method of yugisho in Muromachi bakufu was as follows.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The method of yugisho in the Muromachi bakufu was as follows.
The method of yugisho in the Muromachi bakufu was as follows.

sen.j: まず神前に当事者、奉行衆・公人などの幕府側、巫女もしくは陰陽師が集まり、巫女のお祓いの後に神前に湯を沸騰させる。
sen.e: First the parties concerned, bugyoshu/oyakebito from the bakufu side and miko (a shrine maiden) or Onmyoji (Master of Yin yang) gather before the gods, then after the miko has conducted purification they boil water before the gods.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: First, the parties concerned, the officials from the bakufu side such as bugyoshu (magistrates) or oyakebito (officials who serve the Imperial Court), and a miko (a shrine maiden) or an onmyoji (the master of Yin Yang) gathered before the gods, and then after the miko had conducted purification, they boiled water before the gods.
sen.cmt: 説明を補足しました。奉行衆をmagistrates、公人をofficials who serve the Imperial Courtとしました。
sen.e: First, the parties concerned, the officials from the bakufu side such as bugyoshu (magistrates) or oyakebito (officials who serve the Imperial Court), and a miko (a shrine maiden) or an onmyoji (the master of Yin Yang) gathered before the gods, and then after the miko had conducted purification, they boiled water before the gods.

sen.j: 次に、予め引かれた籤の順番に当事者の代表各1名（取手）が起請文を書いて焼いた灰を飲み込んだ後に湯中の石を取り上げて神棚に置いた。
sen.e: Next, one representative (torite) of each party writes kishomon (sworn oath), burns it and swallow the ash, then picks up a stone from the hot water and places it on the Shinto alter in the order that was decided by drawing lots in advance.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Next, one representative (termed "torite") of each party wrote a kishomon (sworn oath), burned it and swallowed the ash, then picked up a stone from the hot water and placed it on the Shinto alter in the order that had been decided by drawing lots in advance.
sen.cmt: 時制を過去に統一しました。
sen.e: Next, one representative (termed "torite") of each party wrote a kishomon (sworn oath), burned it and swallowed the ash, then picked up a stone from the hot water and placed it on the Shinto alter in the order that had been decided by drawing lots in advance.

sen.j: 取手は以後3日間、湯起請が行われた神前（通常は神社）に留めて置かれ、3日目に奉行衆立会いのもとで双方の取手の火傷の調査が行われた。
sen.e: The torite were held before the gods (normally a Shinto shrine) where yugisho took place for three days, and then on the third day their degree of scalds was examined by bugyoshu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The torite held before the gods (normally in a Shinto shrine) where yugisho took place for three days, and then on the third day the degree of their scalds was examined by bugyoshu.
sen.cmt: 時制を過去に統一しました。
sen.e: The torite held before the gods (normally in a Shinto shrine) where yugisho took place for three days, and then on the third day the degree of their scalds was examined by bugyoshu.

sen.j: 一方に火傷が現れた場合には「失あり」とされ、当該の取手及びその陣営の虚偽とみなされて敗訴となった。
sen.e: If only one of the torite suffered a scald, he was regarded as "at fault" and that torite and his party was considered as making a false claim and they would lose the suit.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: If only one of the torite suffered a scald, he would be regarded as "at fault," and the torite and his party would be considered to be making a false claim and lose the suit.
If only one of the torite suffered a scald, he would be regarded as "at fault," and the torite and his party would be considered to be making a false claim and lose the suit.

sen.j: 双方に火傷が現れた場合には双方ともに不正ありとして当該物件（境相論の場合は土地）を幕府が収公した。
sen.e: If both of the torite suffered scalds, both of them were regarded as unlawful and the corresponding property (i.e. the land in the case of disputes over the boundaries of territories) would be confiscated by bakufu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: If the both torite suffered scalds, they both would be regarded as unlawful and the property concerned (i.e. lands if the case was of a dispute over the boundary between territories) would be confiscated by the bakufu.

If the both torite suffered scalds, they both would be regarded as unlawful and the property concerned (i.e. lands if the case was of a dispute over the boundary between territories) would be confiscated by the bakufu.

sen.j: 反対に双方に火傷が出なかった場合にはいずれも「失なし」として中分による新たな取り決めが結ばされた。
sen.e: On the contrary, if none of them suffered scalds, it was regarded as both sides were "without fault" and a new deal would be concluded by chubun (physical division of the land).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: On the contrary, if neither of them suffered scalds, both sides would be regarded as "without fault" and a new deal would be concluded by chubun (the physical division of the land).
On the contrary, if neither of them suffered scalds, both sides would be regarded as "without fault" and a new deal would be concluded by chubun (the physical division of the land).

sen.j: なお、当事者の一方が湯起請の呼び出しに3回応じない場合には、「召文違背」を理由とした敗訴が確定した。
sen.e: If one of the party concerned did not respond to the call for yugisho for three times, it was definite that the party lost the suit due to "disobedience to summons".
If one of the parties concerned did not respond to the call for yugisho three times, it would become definite that the party lost the suit due to "disobedience to summons."
If one of the parties concerned did not respond to the call for yugisho three times, it would become definite that the party lost the suit due to "disobedience to summons."

sen.j: 江戸時代初期迄、行われていたと考えられている。
sen.e: It is considered that yugisho was conducted until the early Edo period.
It is considered that yugisho was conducted until the early Edo period.
It is considered that yugisho was conducted until the early Edo period.

sen.j: しかし、江戸時代中期になると、公儀による訴訟体制の整備や科学的な考え方をする人が増え湯起請が正しいと考える当事者は少なくなったため、この方法は廃れていった。
sen.e: However, by the mid Edo period, suit system had been improved by kogi (shogunate), and more people had scientific mind and less people thought yugisho was the right method, as a result, this method eventually died out.

However, by the mid Edo period, the legal system had been improved by kogi (the shogunate government) and people had become more science-oriented and accordingly few people believed in yugisho, so eventually this method died out.
sen.cmt: 分かりやすいよう少し表現を変えました。
sen.e: However, by the mid Edo period, the legal system had been improved by kogi (the shogunate government) and people had become more science-oriented and accordingly few people believed in yugisho, so eventually this method died out.

sen.j: その一方で、湯起請は地域においては湯立の風習に変化して各種神事に取り入れられるようになった。
sen.e: On the other hand, in some regions yugisho changed into a habit of yudate, by emphasizing holiness and magical power of water and fire; in yudate after purification by abstaining from eating meat, water is boiled to present to the god, then it is poured over the attending people to pray for rebirth/purification of life and protection, and this habit has became a part of various Shinto rituals.
On the other hand, in some regions yugisho changed into a custom of yudate and became part of various Shinto rituals.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。文法及び分かりづらい表現を修正しました。
sen.e: On the other hand, in some regions yugisho changed into a custom of yudate and became part of various Shinto rituals.

sen.j: 湯立ちの風習は、水と火の神聖・呪性を重視し、精進潔斎を行って湯を沸かして神に献じて参列した人々も浴びることで生命の再生・浄化と息災を願うというものである。
sen.e: In yudate, with reverence toward the holiness and magical power of water and fire, after purification by abstaining from eating meat, the conductor of the ritual boil water, present it to the gods, and at the same time sprinkle it over the attending people to pray for rebirth and purification of life and good health.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。原文には「湯を沸かし～」の主語の記載がないので、「儀式を行うものthe conductor of the ritual」としました。
sen.e: In yudate, with reverence toward the holiness and magical power of water and fire, after purification by abstaining from eating meat, the conductor of the ritual boils water, presents it to the gods, and at the same time sprinkles it over the attending people to pray for rebirth and purification of life and good health.
